title: Inference in Simple Regression
contentHtml:
In simple linear regression, we're interested in making inferences about the relationship between a predictor variable and a response variable.

We'll focus on constructing confidence intervals for the slope coefficient (β) and performing hypothesis tests to determine if the slope is significantly different from zero.
name: Simple Linear Regression Model" },
intuition: Inference in simple regression allows us to quantify our uncertainty about the relationship between variables and make informed decisions.
realWorldApplications: Identifying the impact of marketing campaigns on sales
commonMistakes: Failing to account for the variability in the response variable
Assuming a linear relationship without checking

subject: statistics
title: Inference in Simple Regression
contentHtml:
In simple regression analysis, we often want to make statements about the population slope based on a sample of data. This is where inference comes in.

Given a sample of size n and a model that relates the response variable Y to the predictor X, our goal is to construct confidence intervals for the true population slope β and perform hypothesis tests to determine if the observed slope is significantly different from some hypothesized value.
name: Null Hypothesis" },
intuition: Inference in simple regression allows us to make probabilistic statements about the true population slope, which is crucial in many real-world applications, such as predicting the effect of a new marketing strategy on sales.
realWorldApplications: Predicting the impact of a new feature on customer churn rates

subject: statistics
title: Inference in Simple Regression
contentHtml:
In simple regression, we're interested in making inferences about the relationship between a single predictor variable and an outcome variable.

We'll focus on constructing confidence intervals for the slope coefficient and performing hypothesis tests to determine if the slope is significantly different from zero.
name: Simple Regression Slope" },
intuition: In simple regression, we're trying to understand the relationship between a single input variable and an output variable. By constructing confidence intervals for the slope coefficient, we can quantify our uncertainty about this relationship.
realWorldApplications: Understanding how changes in temperature affect crop yields
commonMistakes: Failing to account for multiple testing when performing multiple hypothesis tests
Misinterpreting the direction of the relationship between variables
